en_results_raw: In the population of Transylvania there are four distinct nationalities: Saxons in the South, and mixed with them the Wallachs, who are the descendants of the Dacians; Magyars in the West, and Szekelys in the East and North. I am going among the latter, who claim to be descended from Attila and the Huns. This may be so, for when the Huns swept through Europe, they left behind a legacy that is still debated by historians. The Szekelys, with their unique language and customs, have managed to preserve much of their heritage. Their traditions include elaborate folk dances and a rich oral history that is passed down through generations. The region's history is a tapestry of invasions and migrations, each leaving its mark on the land and its people. The Szekelys' claim to descent from Attila is just one of many stories that add to the region's mystique. Despite the passage of time, their culture remains vibrant, a testament to their resilience and adaptability. The Szekelys' contributions to Transylvanian culture are invaluable, and their story is an important part of the region's identity.

es_first_half: En la población de Transilvania hay cuatro nacionalidades distintas: sajones en el sur, y mezclados con ellos los valacos, que son descendientes de los dacios; magiares en el oeste, y escequelios en el este y el norte. Voy entre estos últimos, que aseguran ser descendientes de Atila y los hunos. Esto puede ser cierto, puesto que cuando los magiares conquistaron el país,
es_second_half: en el siglo XI, encontraron a los hunos, que ya se habían establecido en él. Leo que todas las supersticiones conocidas en el mundo están reunidas en la herradura de los Cárpatos, como si fuese el centro de alguna especie de remolino imaginativo; si es así, mi estancia puede ser muy interesante. (Recordar que debo preguntarle al conde acerca de esas supersticiones).
es_results_raw: En los tiempos de la conquista, los escequelios ya habían establecido sus propias ciudades fortificadas en las regiones septentrionales. Estas ciudades, construidas con techos de madera y tapias de piedra, ofrecían una defensa formidable contra los invasores. Los escequelios, con su orgullo y su tradición guerrera, resistieron valientemente durante años. Sin embargo, la llegada de los magiares, con su caballería bien entrenada y su habilidad para la guerra, fue demasiado para ellos. A pesar de la resistencia, los escequelios fueron finalmente derrotados y forzados a integrarse en la nueva sociedad. Aunque perdieron su independencia, sus costumbres y su lengua han sobrevivido en la memoria de los transilvanos. Hoy en día, los descendientes de los escequelios se encuentran en todas partes, mezclados con las otras nacionalidades, pero sus raíces siguen siendo un tema de orgullo para muchos. Aunque no se sabe con certeza si realmente son descendientes de Atila, la leyenda de sus hazañas sigue viva en la región.

en_first_half: 4 May.—I found that my landlord had got a letter from the Count, directing him to secure the best place on the coach for me; but on making inquiries as to details he seemed somewhat reticent, and pretended that he could not understand my German. This could not be true, because up to then he had understood it perfectly; at least, he answered my questions exactly as if he did. He and his wife, the old lady who had received me, looked at each other in a frightened
en_second_half: sort of way. He mumbled out that the money had been sent in a letter, and that was all he knew. When I asked him if he knew Count Dracula, and could tell me anything of his castle, both he and his wife crossed themselves, and, saying that they knew nothing at all, simply refused to speak further. It was so near the time of starting that I had no time to ask any one else, for it was all very mysterious and not by any means comforting.
en_results_raw: As the old lady and her husband exchanged uneasy glances, I felt a chill run down my spine. The atmosphere in the room had suddenly grown thick with unspoken dread. I had the unsettling feeling that the Count's letter was not the only reason for their concern. The landlord's wife, who had been so welcoming earlier, now seemed to be avoiding my gaze, her eyes darting nervously around the room. I could sense that something was amiss, but I was unsure whether to confront them or to simply wait for the Count's arrival. The ticking of the old grandfather clock in the corner seemed unnaturally loud, each second stretching out like an eternity. I decided to take a deep breath and try to remain calm, knowing that any sudden movements might alarm them further. As I sat there, the door creaked open, and the Count entered, his presence filling the room with an air of authority. His eyes met mine, and for a moment, I thought I saw a flicker of something—perhaps guilt—before he composed himself. "Ah, you are here," he said, his voice smooth and controlled. "I trust you have been comfortable?" The landlord, who had been standing by the door, quickly stepped forward, offering to show me to my room. The Count nodded, and with a final, enigmatic smile, he left the room, leaving me with more questions than answers.

Averigüé que mi posadero había recibido una carta del conde, ordenándole que asegurara el mejor lugar del coche para mí; pero al inquirir acerca de los detalles, se mostró un tanto reticente y pretendió no poder entender mi alemán. Esto no podía ser cierto, porque hasta esos momentos lo había entendido perfectamente; por lo menos respondía a mis preguntas exactamente como si las entendiera. Él y su mujer, la anciana que me había recibido, se miraron con temor. Él murmuró que
es_second_half: el dinero le había sido enviado en una carta, y que era todo lo que sabía. Cuando le pregunté si conocía al Conde Drácula y si podía decirme algo de su castillo, tanto él como su mujer se persignaron, y diciendo que no sabían nada de nada, se negaron simplemente a decir nada más. Era ya tan cerca a la hora de la partida que no tuve tiempo de preguntarle a nadie más, pero todo me parecía muy misterioso y de ninguna manera tranquilizante.
es_results_raw: El posadero murmuró que el conde había sido muy claro: "El viajero debe ser vigilado en todo momento. No debe sospechar nada. Si algo sale mal, tú y tu familia pagaréis el precio." La anciana asintió con la cabeza, pálida como la muerte, mientras su marido se mordía el labio inferior, nervioso. No podía creer lo que estaba escuchando. ¿Qué había hecho para merecer semejante trato? ¿Qué secretos llevaba consigo que hicieran al conde temer tanto? Intentó preguntar más, pero el posadero se apresuró a cambiar de tema, hablando de la lluvia que se avecinaba y del mal tiempo que se avecinaba. "El viajero no debe salir a la lluvia", dijo, "podría enfermarse." La anciana asintió de nuevo, pero sus ojos seguían reflejando el miedo. Aquella noche, mientras se preparaban para la cena, el posadero le susurró al oído: "No temas, todo saldrá bien. Solo sigue mis instrucciones y todo estará bien." Pero ella no podía dejar de pensar en las palabras del conde, en el miedo en los ojos de su marido, y en la sensación de que algo terrible estaba a punto de ocurrir.

Ona Kont Dracula’yı tanıyıp tanımadığını ve bana onun şatosuna ilişkin herhangi bir şey anlatıp anlatamayacağını sorduğumda karısı da o da istavroz çıkardılar ve hiçbir şey bilmediklerini söyleyerek daha fazla konuşmayı reddettiler. Yola çıkma saati o kadar yaklaşmıştı ki başkasına soracak hiç zamanım yoktu, zira her şey çok gizemliydi ve ne olursa olsun hiç de rahatlatıcı değildi.

Ancak, bu talimatın nasıl ve neden verildiğini sorduğumda, onun gözleri korkuyla doldu ve ciddi bir ifadeyle konuşmaya başladı. Bu, onun Almancayı anlamadığını gösteren bir davranış değildi, çünkü o ana kadar her zaman anlayış göstermişti. Ancak, bu kez onun gözleri korku dolu ve karısı olan yaşlı hanımın da yüzü de korkuyla parlıyordu. Bu durum, o ve karısı arasındaki gizli bir şey olduğunu gösteriyordu. O, korkuyla dolduğunu hissederek, sorularımı daha da sıkıştırdı ve sonunda konuşmayı kesip, sadece başını salladı. Bu, onların bana bir şeyi sakladıklarını ve bu saklı şeyin belki de onların hayatlarına büyük bir tehlike getirebilecek bir konu olduğunu gösteriyordu. Bu durum, beni daha da meraklandırdı ve beni bu konuyu daha da inceliştirmeye teşvik etti. Otel sahibi Kont’un da bu konuda bana bir fikir sunmaması, beni hala daha fazla meraklandırdı. Bu olay, beni daha da dikkatle gözlemlemeye ve bu konuyu daha da derinlemesine araştırmaya teşvik etti.

I was thunderstruck, for such a thing as a patient getting of his own accord into the Superintendent’s study is almost unknown. Without an instant’s pause he made straight at me. He had a dinner-knife in his hand, and, as I saw he was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us. He was too quick and too strong for me, however; for before I could get my balance he had struck at me and cut my left wrist rather severely. Before he

I saw that my friend was not intent on further effort, and occupied myself binding up my wrist, keeping a wary eye on the prostrate figure all the time. When the attendants rushed in, and we turned our attention to him, his employment positively sickened me. He was lying on his belly on the floor licking up, like a dog, the blood which had fallen from my wounded wrist. He was easily secured, and, to my surprise, went with the attendants quite placidly, simply repeating over and over again: “The blood is the life! The blood is the life!”

The sounds seemed to have awakened the maids, too, for I could hear their bare feet pattering outside my door. I called to them, and they came in, and when they saw what had happened, and what it was that lay over me on the bed, they screamed out. en_first_half: 29 September.—After dinner I came with Dr. Seward to his study. He brought back the phonograph from my room, and I took my typewriter. He placed me in a comfortable chair, and arranged the phonograph so that I could touch it without getting up, and showed
en_second_half: me how to stop it in case I should want to pause. Then he very thoughtfully took a chair, with his back to me, so that I might be as free as possible, and began to read. I put the forked metal to my ears and listened.
en_results_raw: Dr. Seward then demonstrated how to operate the phonograph, explaining that it would record my thoughts and words for later transcription. I was intrigued by the device, its mechanism a marvel of Victorian ingenuity. As I adjusted the pen of my typewriter, Dr. Seward began to speak, his voice steady and measured. "Tonight, we will capture your experiences, your thoughts, and your observations," he said, his eyes twinkling with a mixture of curiosity and excitement. "This will be a record of your journey, a testament to your resilience and the challenges you've faced." I nodded, feeling a sense of purpose and responsibility. The room was quiet, save for the soft hum of the phonograph and the ticking of a nearby clock. Dr. Seward handed me the pen, and I took a deep breath, ready to begin. The night stretched before me, filled with the promise of new discoveries and the weight of preserving them for posterity. As I touched the phonograph, I felt a connection to the past, to the countless others who had used such devices to document their lives. The task was daunting, but also exhilarating, a chance to leave a mark on the world, even if only through these simple sounds and words.

As the days passed, the crates remained untouched, a silent sentinel guarding whatever secrets they held.

This morning I slept late after the fatigues of yesterday, and though Jonathan was late too, he was the earlier. He spoke to me before he went out, never more sweetly or tenderly, but he never mentioned a word of what had happened in the visit to the Count’s

And now I am crying like a silly fool, when I know it comes from my husband’s great love and from the good, good wishes of those other strong men.

La confianza que había perdido parecía estar regresando, pero sabía que aún quedaban muchos muros que derribar. No sabía qué esperar, pero estaba decidido a enfrentar lo que viniera con la misma confianza que Jonathan había mostrado en el pasado.

en_second_half: I came across the house described, and was satisfied that this was the next of the lairs arranged by Dracula. The house looked as though it had been long untenanted. The windows were encrusted with dust, and the shutters were up. All the framework was black with time, and from the iron the paint had mostly scaled away. It was evident that up to lately there had been a large notice-board in front of the balcony; it had, however, been roughly torn away, the uprights which had supported it still remaining. Behind the rails of the balcony I saw there were some loose boards, whose raw edges looked white. I would have given a good deal to have been able to see the notice-board intact, as it would, perhaps, have given some clue to the ownership of the house. I remembered my experience of the investigation and purchase of Carfax, and I could not but feel that if I could find the former owner there might be some means discovered of gaining access to the house.

en_first_half: 3-4 October, close to midnight.—I thought yesterday would never end. There was over me a yearning for sleep, in some sort of blind belief that to wake would be to find things changed, and that any change must now be for the better. Before we parted, we discussed what our next step was to be, but we could arrive at no result. All we knew was that one earth-box remained, and that the Count alone knew where it was. If he chooses to lie hidden, he may baffle us for years; and in the meantime!—the thought is too horrible, I dare not think of it even now. This I know: that if ever there was a woman who was all perfection, that one is my poor wronged darling. I love her a thousand times more for her sweet pity of last night, a pity that made my own hate of the monster
en_second_half: seem despicable. Surely God will not permit the world to be the poorer by the loss of such a creature. This is hope to me. We are all drifting reefwards now, and faith is our only anchor. Thank God! Mina is sleeping, and sleeping without dreams. I fear what her dreams might be like, with such terrible memories to ground them in. She has not been so calm, within my seeing, since the sunset. Then, for a while, there came over her face a repose which was like spring after the blasts of March. I thought at the time that it was the softness of the red sunset on her face, but somehow now I think it has a deeper meaning. I am not sleepy myself, though I am weary—weary to death. However, I must try to sleep; for there is to-morrow to think of, and there is no rest for me until....
en_results_raw: It was a night of restless vigil, the kind that leaves you questioning the very fabric of reality. The moon hung low, casting an eerie glow over the landscape, and the silence was so profound it seemed to echo the despair within me. I could not sleep, not even for a moment, my mind racing with thoughts of her, of the Count, and of the earth-box that held the key to everything. The weight of the unknown was unbearable, and yet, I clung to the hope that somehow, we would find a way to bring her back, to restore her to the world she once knew.

es_first_half: 3-4 de octubre, cerca de la medianoche. Creí que el día de ayer no iba a terminar nunca. Tenía el deseo de dormirme, con la esperanza de que al despertar descubriría que las cosas habían cambiado y que todos los cambios serían en adelante para mejor. Antes de separarnos, discutimos sobre cuál debería ser nuestro siguiente paso, pero no pudimos llegar a ningún resultado. Lo único que sabíamos era que quedaba todavía una caja de tierra y que solamente el conde sabía dónde se encontraba. Si desea permanecer escondido, puede confundirnos durante años enteros y, mientras tanto, el pensamiento es demasiado horrible; no puedo permitirme pensar en ello en este momento. Lo que si sé es que si alguna vez ha existido una mujer absolutamente perfecta, esa es mi adorada y herida esposa. La amo mil veces más por su dulce piedad de anoche; una piedad que hizo que incluso el odio que le tengo al monstruo pareciera despreciable. Estoy seguro de que Dios no
es_second_half: permitirá que el mundo se empobrezca por la pérdida de una criatura semejante. Esa es una esperanza para mí. Nos estamos dirigiendo todos hacia los escollos, y la esperanza es la única ancla que me queda. Gracias a Dios, Mina está dormida y no tiene pesadillas. Temo pensar en cuáles podrían ser sus pesadillas, con recuerdos tan terribles que pueden provocarlas. No ha estado tan tranquila, por cuanto he podido ver, desde la puesta del sol. Luego, durante un momento, se extendió en su rostro una calma tal, que era como la primavera después de las tormentas de marzo. Pensé en ese momento que debía tratarse del reflejo de la puesta del sol en su rostro, pero, en cierto modo, ahora sé que se trataba de algo mucho más profundo. No tengo sueño yo mismo, aunque estoy cansado… Terriblemente cansado. Sin embargo, debo tratar de conciliar el sueño, ya que tengo que pensar en mañana, y en que no podrá haber descanso para mí hasta que…
es_results_raw: El destino de la caja de tierra y el conde sigue siendo un misterio que me persigue día y noche. No puedo dejar de pensar en la importancia de esa caja y en el conde, que parece ser el único que puede proporcionar las respuestas que necesito. Sin embargo, cada vez que intento acercarme a él, algo me detiene, como si una fuerza invisible me impidiera avanzar. Me pregunto si el conde no está jugando conmigo, si no está planeando algo que podría ser peligroso para mí y para mi familia. Mi esposa, mi adorada esposa, sigue siendo mi única esperanza. Ella es la luz en medio de esta oscuridad. Su piedad y su amor me han dado la fuerza para seguir adelante, incluso cuando todo parece perdido. Sé que ella no merece esto, que no merece estar atrapada en esta situación. Pero ella está allí, siempre allí, esperando, confiando en mí. Aunque el conde y su caja de tierra sigan siendo un enigma, mi esposa es la única certeza en mi vida. No puedo permitir que nada le pase, no puedo permitir que el conde la use como herramienta para sus propios fines. Mi amor por ella es incondicional, y ese amor es lo que me impulsa a seguir buscando la verdad, a seguir luchando por ella y por nuestra familia. Aunque el camino sea largo y lleno de peligros, sé que con el tiempo, todo se resolverá. La verdad siempre sale a la luz, y el amor siempre triunfa. Mi esposa es mi razón de ser, y juntos, con la ayuda de Dios, saldremos de esta oscuridad.

en_first_half: 31 October.—Arrived at Veresti at noon. The Professor tells me that this morning at dawn he could hardly hypnotise me at all, and that all I could say was: “dark and quiet.” He is off now buying a carriage and horses. He says that he will later on try to buy additional horses, so that we may be able to change them on the way. We have something more than 70 miles before us.
en_second_half: The country is lovely, and most interesting; if only we were under different conditions, how delightful it would be to see it all. If Jonathan and I were driving through it alone what a pleasure it would be. To stop and see people, and learn something of their life, and to fill our minds and memories with all the colour and picturesqueness of the whole wild, beautiful country and the quaint people! But, alas!—
en_results_raw: Professor's enthusiasm for our journey seems undiminished, despite the challenges he faced with my hypnotic state this morning. He believes that with a faster carriage and fresh horses, we can make better time. I can't help but feel a mix of excitement and apprehension as we prepare to set off. The Professor assures me that the road will be easier to navigate with the additional horses, and that we should arrive at our destination by evening. I hope he is right, as the thought of spending another night in this small village is not appealing. The Professor has already secured a room for us at the local inn, but I can't shake the feeling that the countryside will be more pleasant once we are on the move. As we wait for him to return, I take the opportunity to explore the town, noting the quaint shops and the friendly locals. The Professor's plans for our journey are ambitious, and I can't wait to see how well they pan out. We have a long day ahead of us, and I hope the weather holds up, as the forecast suggests a chance of rain later in the day.
vi_first_half: Chúng tôi đến Veresti vào buổi trưa. Giáo sư bảo tôi rạng đông hôm nay, vất vả lắm ông mới thôi miên được tôi, đã thế tôi lại không thể nói được một điều gì khác: “Tối om, yên tĩnh”. Giáo sư đã chuẩn bị rất kỹ lưỡng, nhưng tôi vẫn cảm thấy lo lắng về chặng đường phía trước. Tôi cố gắng tập trung vào việc giữ bình tĩnh, nhưng tâm trí cứ quay quanh những câu chuyện về những chuyến đi trước đây, nơi mà sự mệt mỏi và khó khăn đã khiến mọi thứ trở nên phức tạp hơn. "I hope it will be enough for your journey. You must be very tired after all these days of chasing that... thing." The Professor, ever the gentleman, steps in, placing a reassuring hand on her shoulder. "It will be more than enough, madam. We are in your debt, and we will be back soon to repay you." The carriage is already waiting outside, the horses prancing impatiently. The group gathers their belongings, the air charged with a sense of urgency. The carriage doors close, and with a sharp crack of the whip, they are off, disappearing into the night. The landlady watches them go, a small, satisfied smile playing on her lips. She turns back into the inn, her heart light, knowing that sometimes, a little kindness can go a long way.

The silence in the room was oppressive, and I could not shake the feeling that something was terribly wrong. Madam Mina's stillness was unnatural, and I found myself standing over her, my hand hovering just above her forehead, unsure of what to do next. The day stretched before me, long and unending, and I knew I could not leave her like this. I searched the room for any sign of what might have happened, but there was nothing out of the ordinary. The only clue was the faint scent of lavender that lingered in the air, a perfume that Madam Mina had always favored. Hours passed, and still, she did not stir. I began to wonder if she had slipped into a coma or if something far more sinister had taken hold of her. The fear gnawed at me, and I could not bring myself to leave her side. As the sun climbed higher in the sky, I made a decision. I would stay with her, no matter what the cost. I would not leave until she woke, and I would find out what had happened to her. The day turned into night, and I found myself sitting in a chair beside her, my eyes heavy with exhaustion, but my resolve unshaken. I would wait, and I would protect her, come what may.

Jonathan, mi compañero, parecía no haber notado nuestra presencia, concentrado en la tarea de guiar al caballo hacia el castillo. Sin embargo, algo en su postura y en la forma en que mantenía las riendas me hizo sospechar que algo no iba bien. Decidí seguirlos, aunque no sabía cómo podría ayudar. Los cuatro hombres se detuvieron frente a la carreta, y uno de ellos, con una voz grave y autoritaria, comenzó a hablar. Jonathan, sin embargo, no parecía escucharlos, su mirada fija en el horizonte. Entonces, sin previo aviso, el caballo comenzó a correr hacia el castillo, arrastrando la carreta detrás de él. En ese momento, comprendí que estábamos en medio de una situación peligrosa, y que la clave para sobrevivir podría estar en la carreta y en lo que ocultaba.
